Qualifiers.Scope: Defines the origin point for setback measurements when specific easements are present on a lot.
Qualifiers.Applicability: Applies to lots with 'Creek easements' or 'Public street easements'.
Qualifiers.Exclusions: Most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.

Variables.setback_measurement_origin: The point from which the setback is measured, which can be the 'lot line' or the 'edge of the easement'.
Variables.easement_type: The type of easement present on the lot (e.g., Creek, Public street, Public utility).
Variables.lot_line_location: The surveyed boundary of the property.

Constants.Procedure: Setbacks must be measured from the edge of the applicable easement.

Conditions.Mandatory: If a 'Creek easement' or 'Public street easement' exists, the setback MUST be measured from the edge of the easement, regardless of the lot line location.
Conditions.Ambiguity Flag: The text states 'most public utility easements do not affect setbacks', which is ambiguous and requires clarification for automated validation. It is not an absolute exclusion.

Exceptions.Explicit Deviations: Public utility easements are generally excluded from this rule, though the language 'most' is imprecise and implies some may still affect setbacks.

Relationships.Hierarchical: This rule is a specific consideration within the general topic of 'Setback considerations'.
Relationships.Cross-references: Refers to 'Figure 16', the 'section on Lot Size' for more information about creek and public street easements, and the 'Santa Clara Valley Water District' for information regarding creek easements.

Qualifiers.Scope: Defines the origin point for setback measurements in relation to sidewalks and the public right-of-way.
Qualifiers.Applicability: Applies to lots adjacent to a public sidewalk.
Qualifiers.Exclusions: None explicitly stated, but a conditional exception applies.

Variables.setback_measurement_origin: The point from which the setback is measured, which can be the 'lot line' or the 'edge of the public street easement or right-of-way'.
Variables.lot_line_location: The physical location of the lot line relative to the street and sidewalk.
Variables.public_right_of_way_width: The space between the sidewalk edge and the lot line. Can be 0' or more than 15'.

Constants.Procedure: By default, setbacks are measured from the lot lines, regardless of where the sidewalks are located.

Conditions.Mandatory: The setback must be measured from the lot line, not the sidewalk.
Conditions.Conditional Logic: IF the lot line is in the middle of the street, THEN the setback is measured from the edge of the public street easement or right-of-way.

Exceptions.Special Cases: The case where the lot line is located in the middle of the street, which alters the measurement origin from the lot line to the easement/right-of-way edge.

Relationships.Hierarchical: This rule is a specific consideration within the general topic of 'Setback considerations'.
Relationships.Cross-references: Refers to 'Figure 16', the 'section on Lot Size' for more information about public street easements, and the 'Development Center' for questions on right-of-way width.

extracted_rules.rule: Setback Determination for Oddly Shaped Lots

Qualifiers.Scope: Provides a reference for determining appropriate site plans and setbacks for non-standard lot shapes.
Qualifiers.Applicability: Applies to 'flag lot' (Fig 17 A), 'corner lot' (Fig 17 B), 'through lot' (Fig 17 D), 'wedge-shaped lot' (Fig 17 E), and 'lot with more than four sides' (Fig 17 F & G).
Qualifiers.Exclusions: Standard rectangular lots where setbacks are obvious.

Variables.lot_shape: The geometric shape of the lot (flag, corner, through, wedge, multi-sided).

Constants.Procedure: Refer to Figure 17 on page 23 for the appropriate site plan and setback layout.

Conditions.Conditional Logic: IF a lot has an odd shape for which setbacks are not obvious, THEN refer to the specified illustrations in Figure 17 for guidance.

Exceptions.Explicit Deviations: This section does not contain rules itself, but points to illustrations of rules and exceptions.

Relationships.Hierarchical: This is a procedural rule under 'Setback considerations' that directs users to other rule sources.
Relationships.Cross-references: Refers to 'Figure 17 on page 23' (specifically parts A, B, D, E, F, G).
Relationships.Logical Dependencies: Compliance is dependent on correctly interpreting the visual information and rules contained within the referenced Figure 17.

extracted_rules.rule: Reduced Setbacks for Flag and Substandard Lots

Qualifiers.Scope: Describes specific instances of reduced setbacks for smaller or oddly shaped lots.
Qualifiers.Applicability: Applies to 'flag lots' and 'substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide'.
Qualifiers.Exclusions: Lots not meeting the specified criteria (e.g., standard lots, corner lots >= 50' wide).

Variables.lot_type: The classification of the lot (e.g., 'flag lot', 'substandard corner lot').
Variables.lot_width: Dimensional parameter for corner lots, used to determine if it is 'substandard'.
Variables.setback_type: The specific setback being modified (e.g., 'front setback', 'street-side yard setback').

Conditions.Conditional Logic: IF lot is a 'flag lot', THEN the front setback may be reduced (as illustrated in Figure 17 A). IF lot is a 'substandard corner lot' AND its width is less than 50', THEN the street-side yard setback may be reduced (as illustrated in Figure 17 C).
Conditions.Ambiguity Flag: The text uses 'e.g.,' (for example), indicating these are illustrative examples and not an exhaustive list of all possible setback reductions. This makes it difficult to create a complete validation rule without the full context.

Exceptions.Special Cases: This entire rule describes exceptions to standard setback requirements for specific lot configurations.

Relationships.Hierarchical: This rule defines exceptions to general setback rules.
Relationships.Cross-references: Refers to 'Figure 17 on page 23' (specifically parts A and C).
Relationships.Logical Dependencies: This rule is dependent on the standard setback rules from which it provides a reduction. It also depends on the definitions of 'flag lot' and 'substandard corner lot' and the visual rules in the referenced figures.
